Cases / Constraints
* Please remove the trailing newlines from the input of all the cases (except Validator 2 whose input is correct).

* Please remove the trailing newlines from the output of all the cases.

* Test 4 and Validator 4 violate the constraint on [[m]].

Thanks.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Hi,

Your solution using exhaustive search for both coloring and clique detection. That guarantees correctness, but itâ€™s often overkill for small graphs and quickly becomes impractical on dense ones. A smarter angle might be to reframe it as two optimization problems: how to best approximate a k-coloring, and how to find a near-maximum clique. That way, you keep things efficient and flexible.

I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I want to discuss the difficulty of my puzzle. Please reply if you find it easy, medium, or hard, as I will change the difficulty based on the discussion.

Thank You!

Hi ! I like the idea, graph coloring is very nice. a few remarks/opinions (but I have not tested yet)

- Some images with colored graphs (maybe in the examples) would make it very simple to understand the problem

- I'm not really convinced by the 2 separate problems, as they aren't linked. IIRC if you can prove the largest clique is <k you haven't proven the graph is k-colorable, so players have to solve 2 completely separate problems, as you did in your solution. 
I just think it feels better to be able to get passing tests for 1 problem, and then you can move on to the next. It would also make it easier to understand what to do. Maybe you can do 2 puzzles ?

- This is a very nice and simple example for backtracking, it would make sense to add it to the tags. Are greedy algorithms really relevant here ? same for graph traversal

Goal
* Please change "Determine if" to "Determine if the vertices of".

* Please change "colorable" to "possible".

* Please define "clique".

Input
* First Line: Please change "Contains two integers" to "Two space-separated integers".

* Next m Lines: Please change "two integers" to "two space-separated integers".

* Next m Lines: Please change "u and v ), indicating an edge between vertices u and v." to "[[u]] and [[v]] for the vertices of an edge".

* Last Line: Please delete "Contains".

* Last Line: Please add "for the maximum colors to use".

Output
* Please delete "Line 2".

* Please format "k" as a [[variable]] (twice).

* Please format "YES" and "NO" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

* Please change "clique" to "clique, separated by a space".

Constraints
* Please change 1000 to 10 as n is never greater than 10 in all the cases.

* Please change 10000 to 10 as m is never greater than 10 in all the cases.

Cases
* Please change Validator 2 so that it requires the output of "NO" (similar to Test 2, and please don't make the inputs the same).

Cover picture
* Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.
Is it ok now.
I thought it would be simple, which is why I combined two puzzles into one to make it more challenging and engaging.

Personally I would say either easy or medium for the first part (checking if the graph is k-colorable). Most backtracking puzzles are mediums, but this one is not very complex. Actually as of now you can brute force it as well, since the instances are so small

The clique part is easy, again because the instances are very small and the brute force solution straightforward.

I don't think having both makes the problem harder, just longer. I would advise to separate these 2 into different puzzles, and then for each one, tune the instance size to reach the desired difficulty. 
For k-coloring, I would make it impossible to brute force 100% of the instances, but possible to solve with naive backtracking - then Easy or Medium is good. Then make an optimization problem for the hard version (I can help with that, if you want). 
For maximum clique, I would maybe put it in Hard difficulty and make instances large enough to require some kind of clever backtracking algorithm.

also you can post on the discord server to get more opinions, if you don't get many here. there's time though. Thanks for the work !

Thanks! Youâ€™re rightâ€”exhaustive search works but can be slow for bigger graphs. Approaching it as optimization problems for k-coloring and near-maximum clique makes a lot of sense. Iâ€™ll explore some heuristics or approximation methods to make it more efficient.

Done.
Thanks again.
Thank you for your review. Let's wait for additional feedback.
nice

IMO the first part is already quite challenging for an "easy problem", backtracking is not that simple when you're not used to it. You can compare with other puzzles in the Easy category. Maybe also get other opinions on this.

I would say a better way to make it harder would be to have larger instances. Then players need to incorporate pruning in their algorithm, maybe using clique detection, etc. By the way, this is perfect for an Optimization game (find a coloring with the smallest possible k), as large instances are very hard to solve. Players can use backtracking but also heuristics and metaheuristics. I had thought about making this puzzle some time ago, ended up making vehicle routing instead.
Sure, you can reply to my above comment. How do you feel about the difficulty?
It looks better now. Thanks.
Thanks To You.

"This visual example illustrates how vertices are connected and colored, ensuring no two adjacent vertices share the same color."

What visual example are you referring to?

Thanks.
Reworked on that statement.

The order of explanation is still a bit confusing. "Graph after coloring" is the conclusion for "Graph Coloring", but it's placed after the "Clique" section. I suggest to:

* delete the entire section of "Graph after coloring", and

* add "The graph can be colored with 2 colors while ensuring no two adjacent vertices share the same color." before the heading "Clique".

Another point: the statement gave me the impression one must do the coloring in order to find out the largest clique size. But that doesn't seem to be the case. I think it's better to add a note to clarify that.

Thanks.
Updated the contribution.
